pros:
My psychology team are lovely and good training opportunities within my role so far. 

My clinical lead and manger seem genuinely interested in my professional development.
cons:
The trust is in the process of undergoing major changes with service delivery systems. 

Within this, they are merging adult and older adult services without dedicating more resources to psychology so likelihood is that adult mental health psychologists will be stretched more thinly. 

Also merging physical and mental health so our community mental health team will be overseen by a physical health consultant. 

The general consensus is that the trust have decided the changes without really listening to concerns about these changes and there is no clear planning about what this will mean for frontline staff (a bit like the whole brexit negotiations!) 

Due to the media coverage in recent years, there is a culture of fear and expectation on staff to do more with little sense of these extra unpaid hours being valued.

pros: Southern Health is a very good employer. The employees have very good benefits and are very flexible with time .
cons: One of the biggest downfalls is there are too many managers and not enough staff given to some departments, staff leave and all of the hours seem to go with them and the staff that are left have too cover the work which most of the time is a struggle.When they do employ new staff most of them are apprentices and are unable to do a lot of the day to day  work.

pros: The NHS offer a great package that includes flexible working, a good pension and the fact you know what you are doing is helping others even if not directly
cons: As with all NHS organisations there is a continual challenge of having to do the same or more work with less money

pros: Thoroughly enjoyed my job and the people I worked with.
cons: Did not like driving to and from work in dark winter.

pros: Technology-invested in IT systems for services
